subject: physics
title: Projectile Motion
description: Explore the physics of objects launched into the air, combining horizontal and vertical motion.

labSteps.title: Launch Angle
labSteps.instruction: Set the launch angle to 45° and observe the parabolic path of the ball.

labSteps.title: Horizontal Velocity
labSteps.instruction: Notice that horizontal velocity remains constant throughout the flight — there is no horizontal force.
labSteps.expectedOutcome: Horizontal velocity is constant (ignoring air resistance).

labSteps.title: Vertical Velocity
labSteps.instruction: Observe that vertical velocity changes due to gravity (9.8 m/s² downward).
labSteps.expectedOutcome: Vertical velocity decreases going up and increases going down.

labSteps.title: Trajectory Analysis
labSteps.instruction: Drag the launch speed slider to see how initial speed affects the range and height of the projectile.
labSteps.expectedOutcome: Greater initial speed increases both range and height proportionally.

questions.question: What shape does the trajectory of a projectile follow?
questions.explanation: A projectile follows a parabolic path because horizontal velocity is constant while vertical velocity changes due to gravity.

questions.question: Which angle gives maximum range for a projectile (ignoring air resistance)?
questions.explanation: At 45°, the horizontal and vertical components of velocity are equal, producing maximum range.

questions.question: In projectile motion (no air resistance), what is the horizontal acceleration?
questions.explanation: With no air resistance, there is no horizontal force, so horizontal acceleration is zero.

questions.question: A ball is thrown horizontally from a height. What determines how long it takes to hit the ground?
questions.explanation: Time of flight depends only on vertical motion, which is determined by the height and gravitational acceleration.
